channel.title: CNET News.com
channel.description: Tech news and business reports by CNET News.com. Focused on information technology, core topics include computers, hardware, software, networking, and Internet media.
channel.copyright: Copyright 1995-2008 CNET Networks, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Are Google Maps good or evil?
item.description: Google Maps helps bad people find good people and vice versa. You'll have to decide whether to feel more or less secure.

item.title: Ad firm ContextWeb snags $26 million in funding
item.description: Advertising exchange owner ContextWeb closes funding round of $26 million.

item.title: Viacom CEO Philippe Dauman on Google's 'rogue company'
item.description: Viacom chief says Google has an inability to bend in negotiations with Hollywood and suggests it was always Google's strategy to ignore piracy on YouTube so the site could "dominate the space."

item.title: Will Yahoo ad business weather economic storm?
item.description: Google got off easy with its second-quarter results. It's not clear that Yahoo, with more exposure to display ads, will be so lucky.

item.title: The world's biggest subwoofer
item.description: When it comes to subwoofers size still matters.

item.title: Yang note welcomes Icahn's 'fresh perspective'
item.description: After months of exchanging barbs with investor activist Carl Icahn, Yahoo CEO Jerry Yang tells employees he's looking forward to working with Icahn on the board.

item.title: Opening up the cloud
item.description: Cloud computing needs to be open. Too much is riding on the risk of proprietary closure of data. Suggestion: make it easy (and free) to develop, but charge for services rendered.

item.title: 'Smart' electric grids to ease zap from plug-ins?
item.description: Department of Energy-funded project is testing fast chargers and "smart" electrical grids for controlling a potential strain on resources from plug-in hybrid vehicles.

item.title: Targeted 'Times' articles coming to LinkedIn
item.description: The content-sharing deal enables The New York Times to send newspaper headlines targeted to the individual interests of the business-networking site's users.

item.title: At FCC broadband hearing, speeches but no consensus
item.description: Regulators hold public hearing with few ground rules, resulting in haphazardly meandering comments on spam, porn, privacy, Net neutrality, and copyright infringement.

item.title: Servers in the home remain scarce
item.description: A year after its release, Microsoft's Windows Home Server product still rare on store shelves and well known only among hard core techies.

item.title: GM partners with utilities to advance plug-in hybrids
item.description: General Motors, electric companies, and the Electric Power Research Institute aim to lay the groundwork for stations to charge electric cars.

item.title: Coulomb unveils electric-car charging stations
item.description: Tests of Coulomb Technologies' curbside stations for recharging electric vehicles are coming first to San Jose, Calif, under a two-year contract using the existing infrastructure.

item.title: Green news harvest: Wind power expands in Northwest; lime-laced oceans explored to fight global warming
item.description: A sampling of green-tech news, including a waste-to-fuel plant set for Nevada, criticism of new coal plants, hybrid taxis in the Big Apple, smart homes set for Europe, and more.

item.title: AOL expands health site
item.description: More content and tools--and advertising opportunity--comes to AOL Health from Caring.com, Health.com, and Healthcare.com.

item.title: Report: TiVo, Amazon team up on sales pitches
item.description: Partnership aims to make it easier for consumers to purchase products they see advertised and promoted on television commercials and talk shows, The New York Times reports.

item.title: Amazon offers automatic credit for S3 outage
item.description: Ordinarily, customers would have to apply to get credit for an Amazon Web Services outage, but online retailer is handling Sunday's outage automatically.

item.title: Sandisk: Windows Vista not optimized for solid state drives
item.description: Sandisk says Windows Vista is not optimized for solid state drives, which will cause a delay in the roll-out of optimized drives.

item.title: VCs pin hopes on green-tech 'exits'
item.description: Green-tech sectors--solar, alternative fuels, auto, and wind--are expected to get more money from venture capitalists in the coming year, with hopes of healthy IPOs in 2010.

item.title: Adobe revs media player, signs up Sony
item.description: Haven't seen Jerry Maguire enough yet? New movies from Sony and TV shows from CBS are arriving on Adobe Media Player so you can stream them to your computer.

item.title: Intel cuts chip prices up to 31 percent
item.description:
Featured links from the CNET Blog Network

Intel cuts chip prices up to 31 percent--Cuts to prices of dominant chipmaker's processor prices are limited in number and degree. Largest cut comes to the desktop Core 2 Duo E8500, at 3.16GHz. p>

Replay Solutions on 'TiVo for software'--CEO Jonathan Lindo discusses how enterprise Java developers, like those at game companies, would use its bug replication software to fix applications faster and more effectively.

Dispose of brigade's database on the battlefield--Fujitsu adds a hand crank to hard drive degausser for emergency use.

Hacking Medeco locks--The Last HOPE conference is as much for people interested in hacking the real world as it is for computer techies.
